page1.title: Open sourcing my bucket list with Trello
page1.summary: I needed a way to keep my bucket list available to me so I wouldn’t keep losing track of it, and making it public on Trello seems like a great idea!

page1.title: On stress
page1.summary: A while ago I was about to burn out. Instead of going crazy I chanelled all of that into all of this.

page1.title: Git-flow ain’t scary
page1.summary: I promised I’d write this when I overcame my initial apprehension of git-flow…turns out it’s not scary at all.

page1.title: 5 open source developers tell us how they got started
page1.summary: I was featured in Noel Peatfield's post on opensource.com about how open source developers got started.

page1.title: Front end is dead
page1.summary: I was asked to summarise for a group of IT students what goes into a job like mine, and in doing so I realised that it’s damn near impossible to do so these days…

page1.title: Travis ain’t scary
page1.summary: The final (for now) in the “Front End Ain’t Scary” series of posts, this introduces Travis CI, the continuous integration service.

page1.title: Don’t be an imposter
page1.summary: Inspired by Geek Mental Help Week, I wanted to sum up my thoughts on Imposter Syndrome and on trying to overcome it on a daily basis.

page1.title: Grunt ain’t scary
page1.summary: Moving on to Grunt, the next post in the “Front end ain’t scary” series introduces the popular JavaScript task runner.

page1.title: BEM up your variables
page1.summary: Taking the concept of BEM - Block, Element, Modifier - and applying it to help with Sass variables in my framework.

page1.title: Combine media queries with Gulp
page1.summary: I wrote my first Gulp plugin, a light wrapper for our node-combine-mq task.

page2.title: Yeoman ain’t scary
page2.summary: Another post in the “Ain’t Scary” series, this post introduces Yeoman and gives an example of a basic generator setup.

page2.title: Dammit!
page2.summary: A little Node package I wrote to print out a random curse when something goes wrong!

page2.title: Bower ain’t scary
page2.summary: Another in the “Front end ain’t scary” series, this post introduces Bower and discusses its uses.

page2.title: Generating Pugpig XML Feeds With Grunt
page2.summary: A post I wrote for the Building Blocks blog on generating the XML feeds required by Pugpig to publish a digital publication.

page2.title: Git ain’t scary
page2.summary: Another article in “Ain’t Scary”, where I’ll write little tips to get started with Git via the command line.

page2.title: Command line ain’t scary
page2.summary: This article is part of a new series I’ll write entitled Ain’t Scary, where I’ll write little tips to get you going on things that I’ve just discovered little tips to get me going on.

page2.title: Bash profile shortcuts
page2.summary: I wrote this Gist a while ago and it came in handy last week when I was showing a colleague some handy shortcuts to add to his .bash_profile - so here it is.

page2.title: Getting a git repository going
page2.summary: Another reference for myself so I don’t have to trawl my memory banks (and the internet) every time I set up a new project.

page2.title: The UX five second rules
page2.summary: My review for the O’Reilly Bloggers review program on The UX Five-Second Rules by Paul Doncaster.

page2.title: My Sass media query mixin
page2.summary: A gist of my Sass media query mixin. I keep forgetting to upload and share snippets of CSS/Sass with people who ask, so here it is!

page3.title: Speaking JavaScript by Dr Axel Rauschmayer
page3.summary: My Review for the O’Reilly Blogger Review Program.

page3.title: On Compatibility
page3.summary: On Compatibility or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Dropped Legacy Browser Support.

page3.title: No mouse mornings
page3.summary: Today we had a “No Mouse Morning” at work. Well we tried, I think I’m the only one who kept it up anyway!

page3.title: Review of a web for everyone
page3.summary: Back on to a tech book for my next O’Reilly blogger program review, I chose “A Web for Everyone: Designing Accessible User Experiences” by Sarah Horton & Whitney Quesenbery.

page3.title: London JS Conf 2014 roundup
page3.summary: A round up of the speakers at LondonJSConf 2014 along with links to their presentations.

page3.title: Review of Idea to Invention by Patricia Nolan-Brown
page3.summary: Delving into a non-technical subject this time, the latest book I received from O’Reilly as part of the was “Idea to Invention” by Patricia Nolan-Brown.

page3.title: Review of Learning from jQuery
page3.summary: I was given a copy of Learning from jQuery by Callum Macrae to review for the O’Reilly Reader Review Program.

page3.title: My Google Analytics dashboard
page3.summary: Sharing my Google Analytics custom dashboard with the world.

page3.title: Implementing Google Analytics custom event trackers
page3.summary: A quick tip to help get the most out of user behaviour tracking with Google Analytics.

page3.title: Review of Raphaël JS
page3.summary: I was given a copy of Raphaël JS by Chris Wilson to review for the O’Reilly Reader Review Program.
